course.subject: SOSC
course.name: China's Economic Transformation
course.description: This course explores the origins, processes, and consequences of economic change in China since 1978. It focuses on China's transformation from a closed and state-controlled economy to a market-oriented, increasingly internationalized, and predominantly private economy. It begins with an overview of the Maoist economic system since the communist revolution in 1949. It then examines how the rules governing economic activities have been redefined in major economic sectors since 1978. It also highlights the main features of the new, capitalistic economy and reflects on the issues and challenges that have emerged during the transformation of the economy.
course.prerequisites: ECON 2103 or SOSC 1350 or SOSC 1440
course.exclusions: ECON 4204, SOSC 2230

reviews.author: LouisLOL
reviews.title: heavy worklode, but high grade
reviews.comment_content: I would say the topic is interesting, mainly about the eco regime of mainland China, but generally, it is not too fun, but not boring as well
reviews.comment_teaching: I would say the topic is interesting, mainly about the eco regime of mainland China, but generally, it is not too fun, but not boring as well
reviews.comment_grading: Even though I didn’t listen to the class very much and the exam was terrible, I still got an A- finally. and strongly recommended that tpg students choose his courses, he is very caring for master students.
reviews.comment_workload:
so heavy!!!!!!
presentation
midterm and final exam
pop quiz(require reading)
paper.....

reviews.author: LLLymik
reviews.comment_content: It's about Chinese Economy transformation after 1949. It focuses on China's transformation from a closed and state-controlled economy to a market-oriented, increasingly internationalized, and predominantly private economy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Holz is really a insightful scholar and professor, who will give you some enlightens.
reviews.comment_grading: I am still taking the course. Theoretically, the grading is  composed by presentation, assignment, pop quiz, and two mid-term exams. So far, the grade of assignment and pop quiz is relatively easy to get.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload in this class is relatively high, as pop quiz, assignment , required reading*2 will be asked to do every week

reviews.author: Khanopy
reviews.title: Treasure life... Don't try...
reviews.comment_content: The content per se is interesting. Class material put a lot of emphasis on uncovering the true problems currently face by the Chinese Gov. and its people.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is worse. Professor is capricious, he changes
a lot of the grouping, grading benchmark, etc. after add/drop period. Also, the teaching relies heavily on videos (10 videos / week).
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair. However, there is chance that you will be taking this course with PG students. Based on the same grading curve, you could be disadvantaged.
reviews.comment_workload: This course is by far the worst I have taken in terms of workload. 6-cred would be more appropriate for a course like this.

reviews.author: Kunstants
reviews.title: 課業壓力大，但靚grade
reviews.comment_content: 這門課講的是中國1949年以來的經濟改革和轉型，內容涉及到不同的產業部門、財政和金融體系，政府政策和政治體制，以及具體的城市化和勞動力等問題。這門課綜合地描繪了中國經濟的整體樣貌。
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof使用各種期刊文章和書籍作為教學材料，教學的過程主要圍繞這些paper，但同時也會對這些paper不足的地方進行評價。Prof很有自己的思考和想法。但唯一不足的是他的英語口音聽起來有些“渾濁”，要很仔細辨別才能聽出他在說什麼。
reviews.comment_grading: Presentation、assignment以及quiz這三項都相對容易得full mark，所以最終grade就取決於兩次期中考試的分數。我兩次期中考試的分數都比全班平均分高一點點，最後的grade是A-。我覺得只要在班級平均之上就能進A range，絕對的靚grade。
reviews.comment_workload: 非常重的workload。首先每個星期都有一次assignment，占總成績的16%；然後每次課前都（可能）會有unannounced的quiz，占總成績16%，quiz的內容就是那些要求閱讀的paper，quiz雖說是unannounced，但其實幾乎每節課都有，所以不要抱僥倖的心態想著這節課不會有quiz就不讀這些reading了，paper每一篇都在20頁以上，平均每篇25頁，尤其是在只隔兩天就到下一堂課的情況下，讀這些paper壓力真的非常大；12%的總成績是presentation，這個還好，只要按時交稿並做了pre就能得全部分；最難的是兩次期中考試，占總成績56%，考試時間很緊，全部是主觀題，需要綜合運用上課講到的東西進行回答。

reviews.author: chimz
reviews.title: Definitely, Prof. Holz is my favourite teacher at HKUST.
reviews.comment_content:
**no official textbook**, however, as an idiot of Economics and Chinese political structure, go to read Barry Naughton's book: The Chinese Economy: Transitions of Growth.

This is a mix course of Economics and Politics. Economic Theory is important, esp. Macro-, Updated knowledge in Chinese political structure is also important.

Some readings that I recommend you to read even you are not in the class.
1) Victor Shih: Financial instability in China
2) Elvin Mark: Quantitative Growth, Qualitative Standstill
3) Qian Yingyi: How reform worked in China
4) Mao Zedong: On 10 major relationships (an interesting article in testing your logic)
5) Vivienne Shue: From Heshang to Falungong
6) Michael Hout: A Chinese Approach to Management
7) Perry Link: The Anaconda in the Chandelier: Chinese Censorship Today

After you read this, you will gain better knowledge in knowing what's going on in China. Nowadays, when you are seeking for jobs, these knowledge are helpful.

Personally, I like the topic on Sociology of Scholars doing China Studies most. This is something you won't see in normal Economics Class, but only Holz's class
reviews.comment_teaching:
Super easy-going professor.
He won't take attendance.
He won't urge you to do homework.
He won't force people doing something they don't like.
reviews.comment_grading:
the marking scheme of mid-term is lenient.

Critique: P/F only (in other words, if you have properly done it, you will gain 20 points)

Mid-term: only 1/3 of students take this:
full mark: 70, mean: 67.1, highest: 70, lowest: 60

final:
full mark: 88, mean: 65.9, highest: 83, lowest: 46

total score (100%):
mean: 81.5 (except the one who score 0), highest: 97

Absolutely good grade. Only Prof. Holz can make this. Take this course, when Prof. Holz runs.
reviews.comment_workload:
Optional combination of workload:
All required: One critique (20%) + Final exam (80%, cumulative)

Optional:
Combo 1: Critique (20%) + midterm exam (30%) + final exam (50%)
Combo 2: Critique (20%) + term paper (15%) + midterm exam (30%) + final exam (35%)
You can choose any combo as you like. You can just complete the work as required. However, you cannot shift to any other combo after you have picked one.

reviews.author: haida
reviews.title: Tough but Worth It
reviews.comment_content: It is not based on textbook. Pr selects the reading materials that fits more to the current state of china's poli econ market. You would have to have econ and social science background for this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: You have to read the readings before the lecture!!! the selected readings are bit tough, but the professor explains at the lecture very well. There is no ppt slide, it requires both discussion and notetaking.
reviews.comment_grading: Midterm and Final Exams are both in essay format.
reviews.comment_workload: There is required reading for each lecture, and it is very very important!!   It requires constant hardworking in order to catch up in the course. But worth it!
